message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is a triad of ascites, pleural effusion, and a benign ovarian tumor, which can be cured by removing the tumor. Metastatic colon and ovarian cancer are possible causes of ascites and pleural effusion but do not involve a benign ovarian mass. Nephrotic syndrome is a renal disorder and not likely to cause pleural effusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome presents with the triad of ascites, pleural effusion, and a benign ovarian tumor. In this case, the resolution of ascites and pleural effusion after removal of the ovarian mass strongly suggests Meigs syndrome rather than metastatic cancer or nephrotic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is characterized by the presence of a benign ovarian tumor, pleural effusion, and ascites, which all promptly resolved after removal of the ovarian mass. Metastatic colon or ovarian cancer would not improve with removal of just the ovarian mass. Nephrotic syndrome is unlikely due to the absence of associated symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is characterized by the presence of a large ovarian tumor, ascites, and pleural effusion. Removal of the ovarian tumor usually results in resolution of the effusion and ascites. Metastatic colon and ovarian cancer would not cause rapid resolution of fluid accumulation. Nephrotic syndrome is not associated with ovarian masses or pleural effusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is a triad of ovarian fibroma, ascites, and pleural effusions that can mimic advanced ovarian cancer. However, unlike ovarian cancer, Meigs syndrome resolves promptly after removal of the ovarian mass. None of the other options match the patient's symptoms and response to treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is characterized by the presence of a benign ovarian tumor, ascites, and pleural effusion. The prompt resolution of symptoms after removal of the ovarian mass supports this diagnosis. Metastatic colon or ovarian cancer would not cause a prompt resolution of symptoms, and nephrotic syndrome is not associated with the presence of an ovarian mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is characterized by the presence of an ovarian tumor, ascites, and pleural effusion. Removal of the ovarian tumor leads to prompt resolution of the ascites and pleural effusion. Other options such as metastatic colon or ovarian cancer would not resolve with just removal of the ovarian mass, and nephrotic syndrome does not cause ovarian mass or pleural effusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is a rare condition characterized by the triad of ascites, pleural effusion, and a benign ovarian tumor. The fact that the patient's symptoms resolved promptly after removal of the ovarian mass points towards Meigs syndrome as the most likely diagnosis. Metastatic colon and ovarian cancer typically do not present with a benign ovarian tumor, and nephrotic syndrome is not associated with pleural effusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine. The patient's symptoms, including right-sided hydrothorax, ascites, and a large ovarian mass, are consistent with Meigs syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of ovarian fibroma or fibrothecoma, ascites, and hydrothorax. Metastatic colon or ovarian cancer would have presented with other symptoms, such as weight loss, anorexia, and bowel changes. Nephrotic syndrome would present with proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meigs syndrome is characterized by the triad of ascites, pleural effusion, and a benign ovarian tumor. As the patient’s symptoms resolved promptly after removal of the ovarian mass, this is consistent with the diagnosis of Meigs syndrome. Options A and B are possible, but there is no mention of a colon or ovarian mass in the question stem. Option D is unlikely as there is no mention of proteinuria or edema, which are hallmark symptoms of nephrotic syndrome.
